facts.text: On October 18, 1954, the District Board, Agra resolved to terminate after giving salary for three months in lieu of notice, the employment of the appellant who held the office of Engineer under the Board, and intimation in that behalf was given to him.
An appeal preferred by the appellant to the Government of U. P. against the order terminating his employment was dismissed on December 5, 1956.

The appellant then submitted a petition to the High Court of Allahabad under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of certiorari quashing the resolution passed by the Board on October 18, 1954, and the order dated December 5, 1956, passed by the State of U.P. dismissing the appellant's appeal, and a writ in the nature of mandamus commanding the Board and the State of U.P. to treat the appellant as the lawfully appointed Engineer of the District Board and not to give effect to the resolution terminating the services of the appellant passed by the Board on October 18, 1954.

The appellant averred that he had as Engineer of the Board rendered flawless service but a member of the Board named Tota Ram felt annoyed with him for reasons which had nothing to do with the proper discharge of his duties as an Engineer, and the President of the District Board was not very happy with the appellant for reasons best known to the President, that he had spent the best part of his life in the service of the District Board and even though he has been honest and faithful in the discharge of his duties the District Board, has capriciously and without any justification terminated his services, and therefore the resolution of the Board terminating his services was invalid.

On behalf of the Board an affidavit was filed stating that the appellant was guilty of negligence, and unfaithfulness, and he was censured, his annual increments were stopped, and that he was once dismissed and thereafter the resolution of dismissal was rescinded. The affidavit catalogued several incidents in support of this case.

Specific incidents: censure administered to the appellant for neglect of duty on March 25, 1945; order of dismissal from service on a finding by the Public Works Committee that he was guilty of negligence and unfaithfulness in 1946 (later rescinded); comments made by the Chairman of the Board in 1947 that the appellant had not proved himself to be a loyal and faithful servant; stoppage of increments of the appellant by an order of the President of the Board in 1953 and 1954.

The State of U.P. submitted that the services of the appellant were terminated in accordance with rule 3 A iv of the District Board Manual, that no appeal lay against the resolution terminating the services of the appellant under rule 3 A iv of the Rules regarding Officers and Servants of District Boards and that the order of the State Government rejecting the appeal was correct.

The High Court dismissed the petition holding that under the fourth proviso to s. 82 of the District Boards Act, 1922, the Board had the power to appoint and to determine the employment of an Engineer of the Board and unless the determination was by way of punishment it could be made in the manner provided by rule 3A cl. iv after giving notice of three months or a sum equal to salary for three months in lieu of notice. Judgment and decree dated December 1, 1958.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate granted by the High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court had jurisdiction under Art. 226 to grant writs declaring the termination of employment by a statutory body unlawful and restoring the employee to service.
Whether under the District Boards Act, 1922, the Board is invested with the power to determine employment of a servant otherwise than by way of dismissal as punishment.
Whether the resolution dated October 18, 1954, was in reality a dismissal as punishment camouflaged as termination simpliciter.

petitioner_arguments.text: The power to dismiss conferred by the fourth proviso to s.82 could only be exercised for punishing a delinquent servant after following procedure, and apart from power to dismiss there was no power to determine employment; provisions of rule 3A cl. iv ineffective.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: District Boards Act, 1922 s.82 fourth proviso; rule 3A

petitioner_arguments.text: In absence of specific power to determine employment conferred by the Act, rule prescribing conditions was sterile as Legislature did not confer power to terminate otherwise than by dismissal as punishment.

Even though in form power of determination exercised, in substance it was dismissal and form was camouflage; supported by service history in Board's affidavit showing censures, stoppages, prior dismissal.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant not member of civil service, not entitled to Art. 311 protection; relief claimed restricted by s.21(b) Specific Relief Act; remedy is suit for damages, not writ for restoration.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 311, Art. 226 Constitution; Specific Relief Act s.21(b); Municipal Board Shahjahanpur v. Sardar Sukha Singh; Ram Babu Rathaur v. Divisional Manager LIC; Dr. SB Dutt v. University of Delhi

respondent_arguments.text: Board competent under fourth proviso s.82 to terminate; done per rule 3A iv; no appeal lay; appellant guilty of negligence etc.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: District Boards Act s.82 fourth proviso; rule 3A iv

court_reasoning.text: Rejected preliminary objection: Courts can declare invalid act of statutory body in breach of mandatory obligation, even if compels retention; distinguished cited cases as not involving statutory breach; followed Vine v. National Dock Labour Board.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jurisdiction exists to declare statutory body's action ultra vires even for termination of employment.

court_reasoning.text: Under ss.72,82,84,172 District Boards Act and rules, Board must appoint Engineer; power to terminate simpliciter exists via s.82 (power to appoint carries termination) subject to rule 3A; distinct from dismissal as punishment under 1946 regulation requiring show cause.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Dismissal' in s.82 provisos means punitive; termination simpliciter per rule 3A valid.

court_reasoning.text: No plea in writ petition or HC that order was disguised dismissal; new case not to be allowed in SC; would surprise Board; primarily question of fact not raised below.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Form not conclusive but true nature not pleaded or argued below.

holdings.text: High Court has jurisdiction under Art.226 to declare termination by statutory body invalid if breaches statute.
Board has power under District Boards Act to terminate employment simpliciter per rule 3A, distinct from punitive dismissal.
Resolution of Oct 18,1954 valid termination; no evidence or plea it was disguised dismissal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Board, Shahjahanpur v. Sardar Sukha Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Enunciates common law rule against forcing retention but powers of statutory body subject to statute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Babu Rathaur v. Divisional Manager, Life Insurance Corporation of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Governed by contract, not statute; no writ for restoration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dr. S.B. Dutt v. University of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Contractual service; arbitrator award enforcing personal service void under Specific Relief Act s.21(b).

precedents_cited.case_name: Vine v. National Dock Labour Board
precedents_cited.relevance: Court can declare dismissal by statutory body nullity if ultra vires (no power to delegate).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction for statutory breaches; no Art.311 protection for non-civil servant.

statutes_cited.name: District Boards Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of appointment, dismissal, termination; subject to rules.

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act
statutes_cited.relevance: No specific performance of personal service contracts.

statutes_cited.name: District Boards Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions for termination simpliciter (3 months notice/pay); show cause for punitive dismissal.

outcome.summary: The appeal against the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition is dismissed. The Board's resolution terminating the appellant's services per rule 3A is valid as termination simpliciter, not requiring punitive dismissal procedure, and no case made out that it was disguised dismissal.

key_quotes.text: "It is settled law that the form of the order under which the employment of a servant is determined is not conclusive of the true nature of the order."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Allows courts to look behind form to substance for disguised dismissals.

key_quotes.text: "In the law relating to master and servant the expression dismissal has acquired a limited meaning- determination of employment as a method of punishment for misconduct or other cause."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes termination simpliciter from punitive dismissal.

key_quotes.text: "Power to appoint ordinarily carries with it the power to terminate appointment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for Board's termination power under s.82.
